content: The frequency of irrigation for a mango farm depends on various factors such as soil type, climate, stage of tree growth, and weather conditions. Generally, young mango trees require water more frequently, while mature trees have deeper root systems and can tolerate longer intervals between irrigation. It is recommended to monitor soil moisture levels regularly and irrigate when the top few inches of soil are dry. Consult with a local agricultural expert for specific irrigation recommendations based on your farm's conditions.

Premature mango fruit drop can be caused by various factors such as stress from water deficiency or excess, nutrient deficiencies, fungal or bacterial diseases, pests, extreme weather conditions, or improper pollination. It is important to analyze these factors and address any underlying issues to prevent premature fruit drop. Consulting with a local agricultural expert can help diagnose the specific cause and provide appropriate solutions for your mango farm.
